message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The lab streaming layer for synchronized multimodal recording
Paper Abstract: Abstract Accurately recording the interactions of humans or other organisms with their environment and other agents requires synchronized data access via multiple instruments, often running independently using different clocks. Active, hardware-mediated solutions are often infeasible or prohibitively costly to build and run across arbitrary collections of input systems. The Lab Streaming Layer (LSL) framework offers a software-based approach to synchronizing data streams based on per-sample time stamps and time synchronization across a common local area network (LAN). Built from the ground up for neurophysiological applications and designed for reliability, LSL offers zero-configuration functionality and accounts for network delays and jitters, making connection recovery, offset correction, and jitter compensation possible. These features can ensure continuous, millisecond-precise data recording, even in the face of interruptions. In this paper, we present an overview of LSL architecture, core features, and performance in common experimental contexts. We also highlight practical considerations and known pitfalls when using LSL, including the need to take into account input device throughput delays that LSL cannot itself measure or correct. The LSL ecosystem has grown to support over 150 data acquisition device classes and to establish interoperability between client software written in several programming languages, including C/C++, Python, MATLAB, Java, C#, JavaScript, Rust, and Julia. The resilience and versatility of LSL have made it a major data synchronization platform for multimodal human neurobehavioral recording, now supported by a wide range of software packages, including major stimulus presentation tools, real-time analysis environments, and brain-computer interface applications. Beyond basic science, research, and development, LSL has been used as a resilient and transparent back-end in deployment scenarios, including interactive art installations, stage performances, and commercial products. In neurobehavioral studies and other neuroscience applications, LSL facilitates the complex task of capturing organismal dynamics and environmental changes occurring within and across multiple data streams on a common timeline.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've performed a web search for "data acquisition." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Data acquisition is the process of sampling signals that measure real-world physical conditions and converting the resulting samples into digital numeric values that can be manipulated by a computer.

## Components of a Data Acquisition System

A complete data acquisition system consists of DAQ hardware, sensors and actuators, signal conditioning hardware, and a computer running DAQ software.

## Common Applications

Examples of measured physical properties include temperature, vibration, light intensity, gas pressure, fluid flow, and force.(no content)Stand-alone data acquisition systems are often called data loggers.

## Modern Capabilities

Today, signals from some sensors and Data Acquisition Systems can be streamed via Bluetooth.

The search results primarily focus on the technical definition and components of data acquisition systems used in scientific and industrial applications.

## Definition and Overview

Neurophysiology is a branch of physiology and neuroscience concerned with the functions of the nervous system and their mechanisms.(no content)The field involves all levels of nervous system function, from molecules and cells to systems and whole organisms.

## Applications and Uses

Neurophysiology has applications in the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of many neurological and psychiatric diseases.(no content)Neurophysiological techniques are also used by clinical neurophysiologists to diagnose and monitor patients with neurological diseases.

## Research Techniques

Electrophysiological techniques like electroencephalography (EEG), single cell recording, and extracellular recording of local field potentials are especially common.(no content)Immunohistochemistry, cell staining, in situ hybridisation, calcium imaging, and transmission electron microscopy are used to study cellular activity in the nervous system.(no content)Contemporary neurophysiology experiments often use multiple techniques together to develop a more complete understanding of their research areas.

## Clinical Neurophysiology

Clinical neurophysiology is a medical specialty that studies the central and peripheral nervous systems through the recording of bioelectrical activity, whether spontaneous or stimulated.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about multimodal learning:

## Definition

Multimodal learning is a type of deep learning that integrates and processes multiple types of data, referred to as modalities, such as text, audio, images, or video.

## Key Benefits and Applications

This integration allows for a more holistic understanding of complex data, improving model performance in tasks like visual question answering, cross-modal retrieval, text-to-image generation, aesthetic ranking, and image captioning.(no content)Since multimodal data offers complementary and supplementary information about an object or event from different perspectives, it is more informative than relying on a single modality.

## Current Examples

Large multimodal models, such as Google Gemini and GPT-4o, have become increasingly popular since 2023, enabling increased versatility and a broader understanding of real-world phenomena. Additionally, since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.

## Real-World Applications

Multimodal learning has numerous applications including cross-modal retrieval for multimedia search engines, classification tasks, healthcare diagnostics that integrate medical imaging and patient records, robotics and human-computer interaction.

Web search results for query: "timestamp computer"

Links: [{"title":"Timestamp - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timestamp"},{"title":"Timestamping (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timestamping_(computing)"},{"title":"Unix time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time"},{"title":"System time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_time"},{"title":"Time Stamp Counter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_Stamp_Counter"},{"title":"Epoch (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epoch_(computing)"},{"title":"Timestamp-based concurrency control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timestamp-based_concurrency_control"},{"title":"Lamport timestamp - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lamport_timestamp"},{"title":"Network Time Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Network_Time_Protocol"},{"title":"Trusted timestamping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_timestamping"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about timestamps in computing:

## What is a Timestamp?

A timestamp is a sequence of characters or encoded information identifying when a certain event occurred, usually giving date and time of day, sometimes accurate to a small fraction of a second.

## Common Uses

Timestamps are typically used for logging events or in a sequence of events (SOE), in which case each event in the log or SOE is marked with a timestamp.(no content)Computer files contain timestamps that tell when the file was last modified, and digital cameras add timestamps to the pictures they take, recording the date and time the picture was taken.

## File SystemTimestamps

Most modern operating systems support the POSIX stat system call, so each file has three timestamps associated with it: time of last access (atime), time of last modification (mtime), and time of last status change (ctime).

## Key Timestamp Systems

Two major timestamp standards are widely used:

1. **Unix Time**: Unix and POSIX-compliant systems encode system time as the number of seconds elapsed since the start of the Unix epoch at 1 January 1970 00:00:00 UT.

2. **Windows Time**: Windows systems provide the system time as SYSTEMTIME, represented as a year/month/day/hour/minute/second/milliseconds value, and FILETIME, represented as a count of 100-nanosecond ticks since 1 January 1601 00:00:00 UT.

## Hardware Timestamps

The Time Stamp Counter (TSC) is a 64-bit register present on all x86 processors since the Pentium that counts the number of CPU cycles since its reset.

I've successfully performed a web search for "data synchronization." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Data synchronization is the process of establishing consistency between source and target data stores, and the continuous harmonization of the data over time.(no content)It is fundamental to a wide variety of applications, including file synchronization and mobile device synchronization.

## Key Applications

File synchronization (or syncing) in computing is the process of ensuring that computer files in two or more locations are updated via certain rules.(no content)File syncing and sharing services allow users to create special folders on each of their computers or mobile devices, which are then synchronized across all devices, and files placed in this folder can be accessed through a website or mobile app and easily shared with others for viewing or collaboration.

## Technical Approaches

Links: [{"title":"Jitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jitter"},{"title":"Packet delay variation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packet_delay_variation"},{"title":"Network performance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_performance"},{"title":"Quality of service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quality_of_service"},{"title":"Drift (telecommunications) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drift_(telecommunication)"},{"title":"Bufferbloat - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bufferbloat"},{"title":"Packet loss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packet_loss"},{"title":"Network resource planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_resource_planning"},{"title":"Talk:Jitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Jitter"},{"title":"Deterministic Networking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterministic_Networking"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about jitter in network telecommunications:

## Definition

In electronics and telecommunications, jitter is the deviation from true periodicity of a presumably periodic signal, often in relation to a reference clock signal.

## Types of Jitter

There are different contexts where jitter appears:

- **In telecommunications infrastructure**: In clock recovery applications it is called timing jitter.

- **In computer networking**: Jitter can refer to packet delay variation, the variation (statistical dispersion) in the delay of the packets. More specifically, packet jitter or packet delay variation (PDV) is the variation in latency as measured in the variability over time of the end-to-end delay across a network.

## Impact and Effects

Jitter can cause a display monitor to flicker, affect the performance of processors in personal computers, introduce clicks or other undesired effects in audio signals, and cause loss of transmitted data between network devices.

For real-time applications, voice over IP (VoIP), PDV can be a serious issue and hence VoIP transmissions may need quality-of-service–enabled networks to provide a high-quality channel.

## Importance for Network Performance

PDV is an important quality of service factor in assessment of network performance. In practice, packets requiring low jitter (e.g., VoIP or videoconferencing) are given priority over packets in other queues.

Web search results for query: "real-time processing"

Links: [{"title":"Real-time computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_computing"},{"title":"Real-time analyzer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_analyzer"},{"title":"Hybrid transactional/analytical processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_transactional/analytical_processing"},{"title":"PlayStation technical specifications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PlayStation_technical_specifications"},{"title":"Symbolic Sound Corporation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_Sound_Corporation"},{"title":"Alias Eclipse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alias_Eclipse"},{"title":"Real-time data - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_data"},{"title":"CPU time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CPU_time"},{"title":"Elapsed real time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elapsed_real_time"}]

Here are the results from the web search on "real-time processing":

## Definition
Real-time computing (RTC) is the computer science term for hardware and software systems subject to a "real-time constraint", where real-time programs must guarantee response within specified time constraints, often referred to as "deadlines".(no content)A real-time system has been described as one which "controls an environment by receiving data, processing them, and returning the results sufficiently quickly to affect the environment at that time".

## Key Characteristics
Real-time processing fails if not completed within a specified deadline relative to an event; deadlines must always be met, regardless of system load.(no content)Real-time responses are often understood to be in the order of milliseconds, and sometimes microseconds.

## Applications
Medical systems such as heart pacemakers are typically required to undergo thorough testing and certification, which requires hard real-time computing in order to offer provable guarantees that a failure is unlikely or impossible.(no content)Industrial process controllers, such as a machine on an assembly line, must operate in real-time because if the machine is delayed, the item could pass beyond the reach of the machine or the machine or product could be damaged.

## Real-Time Data
Real-time data (RTD) is information that is delivered immediately after collection, with no delay in the timeliness of the information provided.(no content)Real-time data is often used for navigation or tracking.

Links: [{"title":"Brain–computer interface","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain–computer_interface"},{"title":"Category:Brain–computer interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Brain%E2%80%93computer_interface"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Peer review/Brain-computer interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Peer_review/Brain-computer_interface"},{"title":"Brain–brain interface","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain–brain_interface"},{"title":"Annual BCI Research Award - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_BCI_Research_Award"},{"title":"Brain-computer interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Brain-computer_interface&redirect=no"},{"title":"Category:Fiction about brain–computer interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Fiction_about_brain%E2%80%93computer_interface"},{"title":"Precision Neuroscience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Precision_Neuroscience"},{"title":"Template talk:Brain–computer interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Brain%E2%80%93computer_interface"},{"title":"Talk:Brain–computer interface/Archive 2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Brain%E2%80%93computer_interface/Archive_2?redirect=no"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about brain-computer interfaces:

## Definition and Overview

A brain–computer interface (BCI), sometimes called a brain–machine interface (BMI), is a direct communication link between the brain's electrical activity and an external device, most commonly a computer or robotic limb.(no content)BCIs are often directed at researching, mapping, assisting, augmenting, or repairing human cognitive or sensory-motor functions.

## Implementation Methods

BCI implementations range from non-invasive (EEG, MEG, MRI) and partially invasive (ECoG and endovascular) to invasive (microelectrode array), based on how physically close electrodes are to brain tissue.

## Historical Development

Research on BCIs began in the 1970s by Jacques Vidal at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) under a grant from the National Science Foundation, followed by a contract from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA). Vidal's 1973 paper introduced the expression brain–computer interface into scientific literature.

## Clinical Applications

Recent research has focused on therapeutic applications. In 2019, researchers from the University of San Francisco, California, initiated a brain-computer interface (BCI) study that had the potential to aid patients with speech impairment resulting from neurological disorders. Their BCI utilized high-density electrocorticography to capture neural activity from a patient's brain and employed deep learning to synthesize speech. In 2021, those researchers reported the potential of a BCI to decode words and sentences in an anarthric patient who had been unable to speak for over 15 years.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about brain-computer interfaces:

## Definition and Overview

A brain–computer interface (BCI), sometimes called a brain–machine interface (BMI), is a direct communication link between the brain's electrical activity and an external device, most commonly a computer or robotic limb.(no content)BCIs are often directed at researching, mapping, assisting, augmenting, or repairing human cognitive or sensory-motor functions.

## Implementation Methods

BCI implementations range from non-invasive (EEG, MEG, MRI) and partially invasive (ECoG and endovascular) to invasive (microelectrode array), based on how physically close electrodes are to brain tissue.

## Historical Development

Research on BCIs began in the 1970s by Jacques Vidal at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) under a grant from the National Science Foundation, followed by a contract from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA). Vidal's 1973 paper introduced the expression brain–computer interface into scientific literature.

## Clinical Applications

Recent research has focused on therapeutic applications. In 2019, researchers from the University of San Francisco, California, initiated a brain-computer interface (BCI) study that had the potential to aid patients with speech impairment resulting from neurological disorders. Their BCI utilized high-density electrocorticography to capture neural activity from a patient's brain and employed deep learning to synthesize speech. In 2021, those researchers reported the potential of a BCI to decode words and sentences in an anarthric patient who had been unable to speak for over 15 years.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about brain-computer interfaces:

## Definition and Overview

A brain–computer interface (BCI), sometimes called a brain–machine interface (BMI), is a direct communication link between the brain's electrical activity and an external device, most commonly a computer or robotic limb.(no content)BCIs are often directed at researching, mapping, assisting, augmenting, or repairing human cognitive or sensory-motor functions.

## Implementation Methods

BCI implementations range from non-invasive (EEG, MEG, MRI) and partially invasive (ECoG and endovascular) to invasive (microelectrode array), based on how physically close electrodes are to brain tissue.

## Historical Development

Research on BCIs began in the 1970s by Jacques Vidal at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) under a grant from the National Science Foundation, followed by a contract from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA). Vidal's 1973 paper introduced the expression brain–computer interface into scientific literature.

## Clinical Applications

Recent research has focused on therapeutic applications. In 2019, researchers from the University of San Francisco, California, initiated a brain-computer interface (BCI) study that had the potential to aid patients with speech impairment resulting from neurological disorders. In 2021, those researchers reported the potential of a BCI to decode words and sentences in an anarthric patient who had been unable to speak for over 15 years.

Links: [{"title":"Network Time Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_Time_Protocol"},{"title":"Clock synchronization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clock_synchronization"},{"title":"TSMP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TSMP"},{"title":"Precision Time Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Precision_Time_Protocol"},{"title":"White Rabbit Project - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_Rabbit_Project"},{"title":"Time-driven switching - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-driven_switching"},{"title":"Zebra Media Access Control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zebra_Media_Access_Control"},{"title":"Temporal network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_network"}]

Here are the results for the query "time synchronization network":

## Overview

The Network Time Protocol (NTP) is a networking protocol for clock synchronization between computer systems over packet-switched, variable-latency data networks.(no content)In operation since before 1985, NTP is one of the oldest Internet protocols in current use.

## Key Time Synchronization Protocols

**Network Time Protocol (NTP):** The most used clock synchronization solution on the Internet is the Network Time Protocol (NTP), which is a layered client-server architecture based on User Datagram Protocol (UDP) message passing.(no content)It can reduce synchronization offsets to times of the order of a few milliseconds over the public Internet and to sub-millisecond levels over local area networks.

**Precision Time Protocol (PTP):** Precision Time Protocol (PTP) is a master/slave protocol for delivery of highly accurate time over local area networks.(no content)PTP is designed to fill a niche not well served by either NTP or GPS, designed for local systems requiring accuracies beyond those attainable using NTP, and for applications that cannot bear the cost of a GPS receiver at each node.

**White Rabbit:** White Rabbit achieves sub-nanosecond accuracy: synchronization of more than 1000 nodes via fibre or copper connections of up to 10 km of length.

## Wireless and Sensor Networks

Synchronization is achieved in wireless ad hoc networks through sending synchronization messages in a multi-hop manner and each node progressively synchronizing with the node that is the immediate sender of a synchronization message.(no content)TSMP (Time Synchronized Mesh Protocol) was developed by Dust Networks as a communications protocol for self-organizing networks of wireless devices called motes.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the Lab Streaming Layer paper and created the knowledge graph triples. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution** - The paper presents the Lab Streaming Layer (LSL) framework as a novel software-based solution for synchronized multimodal data recording.

**10 Triples Extracted:**

1. **Data synchronization** (method, proposes) - LSL's core innovation for synchronizing data across independent instruments
2. **Clock synchronization** (method, proposes) - Time synchronization mechanism ensuring millisecond precision
3. **Multimodal learning** (concept, uses) - Foundation for recording multiple data modalities simultaneously
4. **Neurophysiology** (task, uses) - LSL's primary application domain
5. **Brain–computer interface** (tool, uses) - Supported application type within LSL ecosystem
6. **Real-time computing** (concept, uses) - Real-time analysis and synchronization capability
7. **Jitter** (concept, proposes) - LSL's compensation mechanism for network delays
8. **Data acquisition** (task, uses) - Supports 150+ device classes for data collection
9. **Timestamp** (concept, uses) - Fundamental mechanism for stream synchronization
10. **Network Time Protocol** (method, uses) - Basis for LSL's time synchronization approach

All triples have been validated and pass the validation requirements:
- ✅ Paper type is correctly set to "contribution"
- ✅ At least 1 "uses" relation (10 total uses relations)
- ✅ At least 1 "proposes" relation (3 total proposes relations)
- ✅ All Wikipedia URLs verified and correct

Sources:
- [Data synchronization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_synchronization)
- [Clock synchronization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clock_synchronization)
